facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 912 of 1967 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 912 of 1967. Appeal by Special Leave from the Award dated March 3, 1967

facts.text: Appeal is from the Award dated March 3, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra, Bombay in Reference IT No. 1 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Award dated March 3, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra, Bombay in Reference  IT  No. 1 of 1968.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra referred the industrial dispute to the Tribunal on December 31, 1965 under section 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Maharashtra referred to the Tribunal on December 31, 1965, under section 10 1   d  of the industrial Disputes Act, 1947, the industrial dispute

facts.text: Dispute between Ms. Jaydip Industries, Thana, and the workmen employed under them.

anchor.surface_text: between M s. Jaydip Industries, Thana, and the workmen employed under them, arising out of the following demands made by the workmen

facts.text: Workmen demanded monthly pay scales: Unskilled 150-5-200, Semi-skilled 175-7.50-250, Skilled 225-10-325, Highly skilled 350-25-600, effective from February 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Following monthly scales of pay should be introduced for all categories of workmen Rs. Unskilled 150-5.00-200.00 Semi-skilled 175-7.50-250.00 Skilled 225-10.00-325.00 Highly skilled 350-25.00-600.00 The above scales of pay are companysolidated

facts.text: Pay scales based on Bombay Working Class Cost of Living Index Number 480, with DA of 10 paise per day per point rise above 480.

anchor.surface_text: and are on the basis of Bombay Working Class Cost of Living Index Number 480. In case if index number move above 480 for every point rise in Index Number, workmen should be paid ten paise per day as dearness allowance.

facts.text: Employer is a partnership firm consisting of five partners manufacturing paper board at factory in Majiwada within limits of panchayat of that village.

anchor.surface_text: The employer is a partnership companycern companysisting of five partners and is carrying on the business of manufacturing paper board, at its factory situated in Majiwada within the limits of the panchayat of that village.

facts.text: Partnership started in 1959 with capital of Rs. 1,50,000, increased to Rs. 2 lakhs in 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership was started in the year 1959, on a capital of Rs. 1,50,0001-. The capital has since then been increased and it was Rs. 2 lakhs in 1965.

facts.text: Number of workmen employed at time of reference: about 150.

anchor.surface_text: The number of workmen employed in the companycern, at the time of the reference, was about 150.

facts.text: Workmen paid fixed consolidated wages.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen were being paid fixed companysolidated wages.

facts.text: Employer filed written statement dated February 8, 1966 contending no financial capacity due to heavy losses year after year.

anchor.surface_text: The employer companytended before the Tribunal, by its written statement dated February 8, 1966, that it has numberfinancial capacity to pay any additional wages, as it has been suffering heavy losses year after year.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra fixed minimum wages for paper and paper-board manufacturing under Minimum Wages Act by notification dated August 4, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the disputes before the Tribunal, the Government of Maharashtra fixed the minimum rates of wages for the employees employed in scheduled employments including the paper and paper-board manufacturing industry under section 3 of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948, hereinafter called the Act, by numberification published in the Maharashtra Government Gazette dated August 4, 1966.

facts.text: Wages raised in implementation of notification with effect from October 1966: Unskilled Rs.90/month, Semi-skilled 100, Skilled-B 115, Skilled-A 130.

anchor.surface_text: In implementation of the numberification, the wages of the workmen companycerned were raised with effect from October, 1966. The workmen were being paid wages at the following rates, before the date of the award, in pursuance of the numberification - Unskilled Rs. 90 per month Semi-skilled Rs. 100 per month Skilled-B Rs.115 per month Skilled-A Rs. 130 per month

facts.text: Tribunal found total loss for 1960-1965: Rs.78,000, annual average Rs.13,000, company financially stable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal companysidered in detail the financial capacity of the employer on the basis of the balance sheets and profit and loss accounts of the employer for the years 1960 to 1965 and found that its total loss for those years amounted to Rs. 78,000 and on that basis its annual average loss worked out to Rs. 13,000 and so the companycern was number financially stable.

facts.text: Tribunal fixed wages: Daily Unskilled 4.50 (117 monthly), Semi 6(156), Skilled 7.50(195), Highly 9.50(247), linked to Bombay CPI, 7 paise per 10 points.

anchor.surface_text: that the rates of wages for the workmen employed in question should be fixed at the following rates- Daily-rated Monthly-rated Unskilled Rs. 4 .50 Un-skilled Rs. 117.00 Semi-skilled Rs. 6 .00 Semi-skilled Rs. 156.00 Skilled Rs. 7 .50 Skilled Rs. 195.00 Highly-skilled Rs. 9 -50 Highly-skilled Rs. 247.00 and said that The above wage rates shall be deemed to be fixed as at Bombay Consumer Price Index figure For a rise of every ten points in the Index Figure the workmen shall be given an increase in the wages at the rate of seven paise per day.

facts.text: Tribunal held wages fixed were minimum wages, capacity to pay irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also held that wages it fixed were the minimum rates of wages for the workmen in question and therefore, the capacity of the employer to pay was irrelevant.

facts.text: Appellant argued Tribunal wrong in fixing higher than govt min wages without considering capacity.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the appellant that the Tribunal was wrong in fixing minimum wages at higher rates than those fixed by the Government under section 3 of the Act without taking into account the financial capacity of the employer to pay.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal could fix higher minimum wages than govt under s.3(2A) Minimum Wages Act since dispute pending.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the minimum wage can provide ceedings before the Tribunal that the numberification by the Maharashtra Government fixing minimum rates of wages came into operation. The sub-section would make it clear that even after the fixation of minimum rates of wages by the appropriate Government under section 3 of the Act, it is open to an Industrial Tribunal adjudicating an industrial dispute relating to wages payable to the employees in a scheduled employment to fix minimum wages at higher or lower rates, if the dispute was pending at the time of fixation of minimum wages under section 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal considered other awards: Kondivitta Paper (1963), Bombay Metal Factory (1965), Ratan Industries (1966).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then came to the companyclusion, on the basis of the minimum rates of wages fixed by it in the awards in the case of M s. Kondivitta Paper and Board Mills  Private  Limited, Bombay, published in Maharashtra Government Gazette, dated November 14, 1963, page 3750 , in the case of Bombay Metal Factory, published in the Maharashtra Government Gazette dated May 27, 1965  page 1963 , and in the case of Ratan Industries, Bombay, published in Maharashtra Government Gazette dated June 23, 1966  page 1974

facts.text: Govt min wages same for Bombay, Thana, Majiwada.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal companysidered this question and held that the rates of minimum wages fixed by the Government for the city of Bombay, the town of Thana and also for the village of Majiwada, where the appellants factory is situate, are the same and so, the rates of wages at Majiwada are number lower than the wage rates obtaining in the city of Bombay and Thana.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Tribunal's wage fixation as minimum wages, not fair wages.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the rates of wages fixed by the Tribunal were fair wages or wages bordering on fair wages.

facts.text: Supreme Court held capacity to pay irrelevant for minimum wages.

anchor.surface_text: As the rates fixed by the Tribunal were minimum rates of wages as explained in the case of U. Unichoyi v.State of Kerala 1 , we do number think that the capacity of the industry to pay was a relevant companysideration.

facts.text: Factory situated outside city of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the appellant that the employer has his place of business outside the city of Bombay

concepts.unlisted_description: Power of government to refer industrial dispute to tribunal

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the disputes before the Tribunal, the Government of Maharashtra fixed the minimum rates of wages for the employees employed in scheduled employments including the paper and paper-board manufacturing industry under section 3 of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948, hereinafter called the Act, by numberification published in the Maharashtra Government Gazette dated August 4, 1966.

concepts.unlisted_description: Fixation of minimum rates of wages by appropriate government

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1  of the Act provides that the appropriate Government may fix the minimum rates of wages payable to em- ployees employed in employments specified in Part I or Part R of the Schedule thereof and in any employment added to either part by numberification under section 27. By clause  b  of section 3 1 , the appropriate Government is given power to review

concepts.interpretation: Power to review minimum wages at intervals not exceeding five years

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the workmen employed in the city of Bombay as affording criteria for f

concepts.unlisted_description: Review and revision of minimum wages

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the minimum wage can provide ceedings before the Tribunal that the numberification by the Maharashtra Government fixing minimum rates of wages came into operation. The sub-section would make it clear that even after the fixation of minimum rates of wages by the appropriate Government under section 3 of the Act, it is open to an Industrial Tribunal adjudicating an industrial dispute relating to wages payable to the employees in a scheduled employment to fix minimum wages at higher or lower rates, if the dispute was pending at the time of fixation of minimum wages under section 3 of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Permits industrial tribunal to fix higher or lower minimum wages than government fixation under s3 if dispute pending

anchor.surface_text: In companysidering the question what are the companyponent elements of minimum wages, this Court observed as follows in U. Unichoyi v. State of Kerala 1  - Sometimes the minimum wage is described as a bare minimum wage in order to distinguish it from the wage structure which is subsistence plus or fair wage, but too much emphasis on the adjective bare in relation to the minimum wage is apt to lead to the erroneous assumption that the maintenance wage is a wage which enables the worker to companyer his bare physical needs and keep himself just above starvation. That clearly is number intended by the companycept of minimum wage.

concepts.interpretation: Includes not only bare sustenance but preservation of worker's efficiency; capacity to pay irrelevant; should be near lower level of fair wage
concepts.unlisted_description: Components ensuring sustenance, family maintenance, and worker efficiency as per U. Unichoyi v. State of Kerala

arguments.claim: Once government fixes minimum wages under section 3, tribunal cannot fix higher rates as minimum wages; higher rates are fair wages requiring capacity consideration

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the argument was that when once the appropriate Government has fixed minimum rates of wages in the employment under section 3 of the Act, it was number open to the Tribunal to fix higher rates of wages as minimum wages and, therefore, the rates of wages fixed by the Tribunal were number minimum wages, but fair wages, or at any rate wages bordering on fair wages, and so, the financial capacity of the employer to bear the additional burden should have been taken into account.

Kondivitta Paper and Board Mills  Private  Limited, Bombay, published in Maharashtra Government Gazette, dated November 14, 1963, page 3750 , in the case of Bombay Metal Factory, published in the Maharashtra Government Gazette dated May 27, 1965  page 1963 , and in the case of Ratan Industries, Bombay, published in Maharashtra Government Gazette dated June 23, 1966  page 1974

holdings.text: Even after the fixation of minimum rates of wages by the appropriate Government under section 3 of the [Minimum Wages] Act, it is open to an Industrial Tribunal adjudicating an industrial dispute relating to wages payable to the employees in a scheduled employment to fix minimum wages at higher or lower rates, if the dispute was pending at the time of fixation of minimum wages under section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the minimum wage can provide ceedings before the Tribunal that the numberification by the Maharashtra Government fixing minimum rates of wages came into operation. The sub-section would make it clear that even after the fixation of minimum rates of wages by the appropriate Government under section 3 of the Act, it is open to an Industrial Tribunal adjudicating an industrial dispute relating to wages payable to the employees in a scheduled employment to fix minimum wages at higher or lower rates, if the dispute was pending at the time of fixation of minimum wages under section 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of section 3(2A) Minimum Wages Act, which excludes applicability of government notification during pendency of tribunal proceedings on wage dispute.

holdings.text: In the light of the provisions of section 3(2A) of the Act, the Tribunal was not bound by the rates of minimum wages fixed by the Government under section 3 of the Act and it was open to the Tribunal to fix rates of minimum wages to be paid to the workmen concerned in the disputes at figures higher than those fixed by the Government.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the provisions of section 3  2A  of the Act, we hold that the Tribunal was number bound by the rates of minimum wages fixed by the Government under section 3 of the Act and that it was open to the Tribunal to fix rates of minimum wages to be paid to the workmen companycerned in the disputes at figures higher than those fixed by the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit holding based on textual interpretation of s.3(2A) permitting variation by tribunal for pending disputes notwithstanding government fixation.

holdings.text: The rates of wages fixed by the Tribunal were minimum rates of wages, not fair wages or wages bordering on fair wages.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the rates of wages fixed by the Tribunal were fair wages or wages bordering on fair wages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal referenced prior awards, cost of living indices, and components of minimum wage per U. Unichoyi precedent; rates do not exceed minimum threshold.

holdings.text: As the rates fixed by the Tribunal were minimum rates of wages as explained in U. Unichoyi v. State of Kerala, the capacity of the industry to pay was not a relevant consideration.

anchor.surface_text: As the rates fixed by the Tribunal were minimum rates of wages as explained in the case of U. Unichoy v.State of Kerala 1 , we do number think that the capacity of the industry to pay was a relevant companysideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying binding precedent from U. Unichoyi that employer capacity is irrelevant to minimum wage determination.

holdings.text: The Tribunal did not go wrong in taking into account the rates of minimum wages fixed in the several awards for the workmen employed in the city of Bombay as affording criteria for fixing minimum rates of wages with suitable modification for the workmen employed under the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We do number, therefore, think that the Tribunal went wrong in taking into account the rates of minimum wages fixed in the several awards for the workmen employed in the city of Bombay as affording criteria for fixing minimum rates of wages with suitable modification for the workmen employed under the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government fixed uniform minimum wages across Bombay, Thana, and Majiwada; no disparity justifying distinction from city awards.

Section 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act provides the statutory basis for referring wage disputes to an Industrial Tribunal, enabling the holding that the Tribunal retains authority to fix wages post-government minimum wage fixation.
Section 10(1)(d) addresses the Tribunal's jurisdiction over wage disputes, which is central to the issue of whether the Tribunal could lawfully fix rates higher than government-set minimums.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the minimum wage can provide ceedings before the Tribunal that the numberification by the Maharashtra Government fixing minimum rates of wages came into operation. The sub-section would make it clear that even after the fixation of minimum rates of wages by the appropriate Government under section 3 of the Act, it is open to an Industrial Tribunal adjudicating an industrial dispute relating to wages payable to the employees in a scheduled employment to fix minimum wages at higher or lower rates, if the dispute was pending at the time of fixation of minimum wages under section 3 of the Act.
